chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will analyze the reason why different companies operate under different amounts of debt.

In order to solve this, we will look at the debt-to-equity ratio of three companies: Bank of America (BAC), Cisco (CSCO), and Chevron (CVX).

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bank of America}&=1.138\\
\text{Cisco}&=0.2331\\
\text{Chevron}&=0.2006
\end{aligned}$$

Here, we can see that the companies operate at different values of debt. However, we can also see that Cisco and Chevron have almost similar debt-to-equity ratios. 

The difference in the debt-to-equity ratios can be attributed to the nature of the company. Different types of services provided by the company can also create a different amount of debt/equity, thus, there is a difference in the debt-to-equity ratio among the three companies.
